text:
They owe me money and I will collect. I will have
them jailed, if I have to. They owe me money and I will
collect what is due me.

What are you doing, Cratchit? Acting cold, are
you? Next, you’ll be asking to replenish your coal from my
coal-box, won’t you? Well, save your breath, Cratchit! Unless
you’re prepared to find employ elsewhere!
Bah! Humbug!

I do! Merry Christmas? What right do you have to
be merry? What reason have you to be merry? You’re poor
enough!
Bah! Humbug!

What else can I be? Eh? When I live in a world of
fools such as this? Merry Christmas? What’s Christmastime
to you but a time of paying bills without any money; a time
for finding yourself a year older, but not an hour richer. If I
could work my will, every idiot who goes about with “Merry
Christmas” on his lips, should be boiled with his own
pudding, and buried with a stake of holly through his heart.
He should!

Nephew! You keep Christmas in your own way
and let me keep it in mine.

Let me leave it alone, then. Much good it has ever
done you!

Let me hear another sound from you
and you’ll keep your Christmas by losing your situation.  You’re quite a powerful speaker, sir. I wonder you
don’t go into Parliament.

I’d rather see myself dead than see myself with
your family!
Why did you get married?

That, sir, is the only thing that you have said to me
in your entire lifetime which is even more ridiculous than
“Merry Christmas!”  Good afternoon.
Good afternoon, Nephew!
Good afternoon!
Good afternoon!

Oh, fine, a perfection, just
fine . . . to see the perfect pair of you; husbands, with wives
and children to support . . . my clerk there earning fifteen
shillings a week . . . and the perfect pair of you, talking about
a Merry Christmas!  I’ll retire to Bedlam!

Mr. Marley has been dead these seven years. He
died seven years ago this very night.

. . . Good
afternoon.
Are there no prisons?

And aren’t the Union workhouses still in
operation?
The Treadmil and the Poor Law are in full vigor, then?

Ohhh, I see. I was afraid, from what you said at
first, that something had occurred to stop them from their
useful course.  I’m glad to hear it.
Nothing!

I wish to be left alone!  Since you ask me what I wish, gentlemen, that is
my answer. I help to support the establishments that I have
mentioned: they cost enough: and those who are badly off
must go there.

It’s not my business. It’s enough for a man to
understand his own business, and not to interfere with other
people’s. Mine occupies me constantly. Good afternoon,
gentlemen!

Take your leave of
my offices, sirs, while I am still smiling.

It’s less of a time of year for being merry, and more
a time of year for being loony . . . if you ask me.
Saved by six bells, are you?

Hmmm. Oh, you’ll be wanting the whole day
tomorrow, I suppose?

It’s not convenient, and it’s not fair. If I was to stop
half-a-crown for it, you’d think yourself ill-used, I’ll be bound?

And yet, you don’t think me ill-used when I pay a
day’s wages for no work . . .

A poor excuse for picking a man’s pocket every
25th of December! But l suppose you must have the whole
day. Be here all the earlier the next morning!
Don’t say it, Cratchit. I warn you . . .
Cratchit!
Bah! Humbug! Christmas! Bah! Humbug!

No light at all . . . no moon . . . that is what is at the
center of Christmas Eve: dead black: void . . .
Pooh, pooh!
Bah! Humbug!

Bah still! Humbug still! This is not happening! I won’t
believe it!
How now! What do you want of me?
Who are you?
Who were you then?
I see . . . can you sit down?
Do it then.
I don’t.

Because every little thing affects them. A slight
disorder of the stomach makes them cheat. You may be an
undigested bit of beef, a blot of mustard, a crumb of cheese, a
fragment of an underdone potato. There’s more of gravy than
of grave about you, whatever you are!
Humbug! I tell you: humbug!

Mercy! Dreadful apparition, mercy! Why, O! why do you
trouble me so?

I do. I must. But why do spirits such as you walk
the earth? And why do they come to me?

Jacob. Old Jacob Marley, tell me more. Speak
comfort to me, Jacob . . .

But you were always a good man of business,
Jacob.

I will, but don’t be hard upon me. And don’t be
flowery, Jacob! Pray!
You were always a good friend to me. Thank’ee!

Would that be the chance and hope you mentioned,
Jacob?
I think I’d rather not.

Couldn’t I take ’em all at once, and get it over,
Jacob?

Jacob! No, Jacob! Don’t
leave me! I’m frightened!  No one here at all! Did I imagine all that?
Humbug!  I did imagine it. It only
happened in my foulest dream-mind, didn’t it? An
undigested bit of . . .  Sorry! Sorry!

Midnight! Why this isn’t possible. It
was past two when I went to bed. An icicle must have gotten
into the clock’s works! I couldn’t have slept through the
whole day and far into another night. It isn’t possible that
anything has happened to the sun, and this is twelve at noon!
 Night, still.
Quiet, normal for the season, cold. It is certainly not noon.
I cannot in any way afford to lose my days. Securities come
due, promissory notes, interest on investments: these are
things that happen in the daylight! 
Was this a dream?

Another quarter and it’ll be one and Marley’s
ghostly friends will come.  Where’s the chime
for one?  A quarter past  Half-past!
 A quarter to it! But where’s the heavy bell of the
hour one? This is a game in which I lose my senses! Perhaps,
if I allowed myself another short doze . . .
A hand! Who owns it! Hello!
Are you the Spirit, sir, whose coming was foretold to me?
Who, and what are you?
Long past?

May I ask, please, sir, what business you have here
with me?

Not to sound ungrateful, sir, and really, please do
understand that I am plenty obliged for your concern, but,
really, kind spirit, it would have done all the better for my
welfare to have been left alone altogether, to have slept
peacefully through this night.
My what?
Fly, but I am a mortal and cannot fly!

Good Heaven! I was bred in this place. I was a
boy here!

Upon my cheek? Nothing . . . a blemish on the skin
from the eating of overmuch grease . . . nothing . . . 
Kind Spirit of Christmas Past, lead me where you will, but
quickly! To be stagnant in this place is, for me, unbearable!
Past. You recollect the way?

Remember it! I would know it blindfolded! My
bridge, my church, my winding river!

Listen! I know these men! I remember the beauty of
their song!
None. No good. None . . .
I cannot look on him!

It’s me.  Poor boy. He lived inside his
head . . . alone . . .  poor boy.  I wish . . .  ah! it’s too late!
Past. What is the matter?

There was a boy singing a Christmas Carol outside
my door last night. I should like to have given him
something: that’s all.

Look! Me, again! Older now!  Oh, yes . . .
still alone.
Yes, sir, I know sir . . .

Oh, my dear, dear little sister, Fan . . . how I
loved her.
So she had.
One child.
Yes.
Know it? Wasn’t I apprenticed there?

Why, it’s old Fezziwig! Bless his heart; it’s
Fezziwig, alive again!
Quittin’ time . . .

Dick Wilkins, to be sure! My fellow-’prentice! Bless
my soul, yes. There he is. He was very much attached to me,
was Dick. Poor Dick! Dear, dear!
Small!

It isn’t that! It isn’t that, Spirit. Fezziwig had the
power to make us happy or unhappy; to make our service
light or burdensome; a pleasure or a toil. The happiness he
gave is quite as great as if it cost him a fortune.
Nothing particular.

No, no. l should like to be able to say a word or two
to my clerk just now! That’s all!
No!
No!
Don’t release me, madame . . .
Ah, yes!
Please, I . . . I . . .
No!
No!
Don’t let her go!
No!
You fool! Mindless loon! You fool!
Don’t say that! Spirit, remove me from this place.
Remove me! I cannot bear it!
Leave me! Take me back! Haunt me no longer!

One! One! This is it; time! 
Nothing!
Midnight! How can this be? I’m sleeping backwards.

Good heavens! One again! I’m sleeping back and forth!
 Nothing! Absolutely nothing!
What?
Just checking to see if anyone is in here.
Hello. How should I call you?
Never.

I don’t think I have. I’m afraid I’ve not. Have you
had many brothers, Spirit?

A tremendous family to provide for!  Spirit, conduct me where you will. I went forth last
night on compulsion, and learnt a lesson which is working
now. Tonight, if you have aught to teach me, let me profit
by it.
What is it you sprinkle from your torch?

Do you sprinkle your kindness on any particular
people or on all people?
Why to the very poor most?
What is this place, Spirit?

Do you mean Cratchit, Spirit? Do you mean this is
Cratchit’s home?
These children are his?
On his meager earnings! What foolishness!

Wouldn’t you say so? Fifteen shillings4 a week’s
what he gets!
Spirit, tell me if Tiny Tim will live.
No, no, kind Spirit! Say he will be spared!
Huh? What’s that? Who calls?
Me, Bob? You toast me?
Oh. Spirit, must I? . . .

Just here, kind madam . . . out of sight, out
of sight . . .

Thank you, Bob . . . and Mrs. Cratchit, too. No
one else is toasting me, . . . not now . . . not ever. Of that
I am sure . . .

I am listening.  Spirit, it must be time for us to
take our leave. I feel in my heart that it is . . . that I must think
on that which I have seen here . . .
What is this place? We’ve moved from the mines!
It is my nephew! . . . and the one he married . . .
It’s me they talk of, isn’t it, Spirit?
What he says is true, Spirit . . .

Spirit, please, make me visible! Make me audible!
I want to talk with my nephew and my niece!

Your hair has gone gray! Your skin, wrinkled! Are
spirits’ lives so short?
Tonight?
Who are they?
Have they no refuge or resource?
Spirit, I’m frightened! Don’t leave me! Spirit!

Who are you, Phantom? Oh, yes. I think I know
you! You are, are you not, the Spirit of Christmas Yet to
Come?  And you are about to show me the shadows
of the things that have not yet happened, but will happen in
time before us. Is that not so, Spirit?  Oh, Ghost of the Future, I fear you more than any
Specter I have seen! But, as I know that your purpose is to do
me good and as I hope to live to be another man from what I
was, I am prepared to bear you company. 
Lead on, then, lead on. The night is waning fast, and it is
precious time to me. Lead on, Spirit!

Spirit, why did you show me this? Why do you
show me businessmen from my streets as they take the death
of Jacob Marley? That is a thing past. You are future!

OOOOOOOoooooOOOOOoooooOOOOOOOO
oooooOOOOOOoooooOO!

OOoooOOoooOOOoooOOOoooOOoooOOoooOOOooo!
 Obscene demons! Why not market the
corpse itself, as sell its trimming???  Oh, Spirit, I see
it, I see it! This unhappy man—this stripped-bare corpse . . .
could very well be my own. My life holds parallel! My life
ends that way now!

Spirit, this is a fearful place. In leaving it, I shall not leave its
lesson, trust me. Let us go!

Spirit, let me see some tenderness connected with a death, or
that dark chamber, which we just left now, Spirit, will be
forever present to me.

Huh? Who
spoke? Who said that?

Specter, something informs me that our parting
moment is at hand. I know it, but I know not how I know it.

Am I that man those ghoulish parasites7 so gloated over?
 Before I draw nearer to that stone to which you
point, answer me one question. Are these the shadows
of things that will be, or the shadows of things that MAY
be, only?
Oh, no. Spirit! Oh, no, no!

Spirit! Hear me! I am not the man I was. I will not be the man
I would have been but for this intercourse. Why show me
this, if I am past all hope?

Oh. Good Spirit, I see by your wavering hand that your good
nature intercedes for me and pities me. Assure me that I yet
may change these shadows that you have shown me by an
altered life!

I will honor Christmas in my heart and try to keep it all the
year. I will live in the Past, the Present, and the Future. The
Spirits of all Three shall strive within me. I will not shut out
the lessons that they teach. Oh, tell me that I may sponge
away the writing that is upon this stone!

Spirit, dear Spirit, I am praying before you. Give me a
sign that all is possible. Give me a sign that all hope for me
is not lost. Oh, Spirit, kind Spirit, I beseech thee: give me
a sign . . .

I will live in
the Past, in the Present, and in the Future! The Spirits of all
Three shall strive within me!

Oh, Jacob Marley! Wherever you are, Jacob, know
ye that I praise you for this! I praise you . . . and heaven . . .
and Christmastime!  I say it
to you on my knees, old Jacob, on my knees!  Not torn down. My bed curtains are not at all
torn down! Rings and all, here they are! They are here: I am
here: the shadows of things that would have been, may now
be dispelled. They will be, Jacob! I know they will be!

I am light as a feather, I am happy as an angel. I am as merry
as a schoolboy. 
Merry Christmas to everybody! Merry Christmas to
everybody! A Happy New Year to all the world! Hallo here!
Whoop! Whoop! Hallo! Hallo! I don’t know what day of the
month it is! I don’t care! I don’t know anything! I’m quite a
baby! I don’t care! I don’t care a fig! I’d much rather be a baby than be an old wreck like me or Marley! (Sorry, Jacob.
wherever ye be!) Hallo! Hallo there!

Hey, you boy!
What’s today? What day of the year is it?

It’s Christmas Day, is it? Whoop! Well, I haven’t
missed it after all, have I? The Spirits did all they did in one
night. They can do anything they like, right? Of course they
can! Of course they can!
Huh? Oh, yes, of course. What’s your name, lad?

Adam! What a fine, strong name! Do you know the
poulterer’s in the next street but one, at the corner?

A remarkable boy! An intelligent boy! Do you
know whether the poulterer’s have sold the prize turkey that
was hanging up there? I don’t mean the little prize turkey,
Adam. I mean the big one!
I mean, the turkey the size of Adam: that’s the bird!

It is? Go and buy it! No, no. I am absolutely in
earnest. Go and buy it and tell ’em to bring it here, so that I
may give them the directions to where I want it delivered, as
a gift. Come back here with the man, Adam, and I’ll give you
a shilling. Come back here with him in less than five minutes,
and I’ll give you half-a-crown!
You are truly a champion, Adam . . .

Oh, my, MY!!! Look at the size of that turkey, will
you! He never could have stood upon his legs, that bird! He
would have snapped them off in a minute, like sticks of sealingwax! Why you’ll never be able to carry that bird to Camden-Town, I’ll give you money for a cab . . .

Oh, I didn’t tell you? Yes, I’ve written the precise
address down just here on this . . .  Bob
Cratchit’s house. Now he’s not to know who sends him this.
Do you understand me? Not a word . . .

Good. There you go then . . . this is for the
turkey . . .  . . . and this is for the taxi.  . . .
and this is for your world-record run, Adam . . .
Then keep it, my lad. It’s Christmas!
Of course I have, sir. It’s Christmas!
Merry Christmas, madam . . .
Merry Christmas, sir.

Oh, you! My dear sir! How do you do? I do hope
that you succeeded yesterday! It was very kind of you.
A Merry Christmas.

Yes, Scrooge is my name though I’m afraid you
may not find it very pleasant. Allow me to ask your pardon.
And will you have the goodness to—

If you please. Not a farthing10 less. A great many
back payments are included in it, I assure you. Will you do
me that favor?

Don’t say anything, please. Come
and see me. Will you?

Thank’ee, I am much obliged to you. I thank you
fifty times. Bless you!
Fred!
It’s I. Your Uncle Scrooge.
I have come to dinner. May I come in, Fred?

What do you mean by coming in here at this time
of day, a full eighteen minutes late, Mr. Cratchit? Hallo, sir?
Do you hear me?

You are? Yes, I certainly think you are. Step this
way, sir, if you please . . .

Now, I’ll tell you what, Cratchit. I am not going to
stand this sort of thing any longer. And therefore . . .
I am . . . about . . . to . . . raise . . . your salary.

A Merry Christmas, Bob . . . 
A merrier Christmas, Bob, my good fellow! than I have given
you for many a year. I’ll raise your salary and endeavor to
assist your struggling family and we will discuss your affairs
this very afternoon over a bowl of smoking bishop.11 Bob!
Make up the fires and buy another coal scuttle before you dot
another i, Bob. It’s too cold in this place! We need warmth
and cheer, Bob Cratchit! Do you hear me? DO . . . YOU . . .
HEAR . . . ME?
